refnamediv.refpurpose: deploy a set of NixOS machines

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Charon is a tool for deploying NixOS machines in a network or cloud.

listitem.para: Path to the state file that contains the deployments. It defaults to the value of the CHARON_STATE environment variable, or ~/.charon/deployments.charon if that one is not defined. It must have extension .charon. The state file is actually a SQLite database that can be inspected using the sqlite3 command (for example, sqlite3 network.charon .dump). If it does not exist, it is created automatically.
UUID or symbolic name of the deployment on which to operate. Defaults to the value of the CHARON_DEPLOYMENT environment variable.
Automatically confirm “dangerous” actions, such as terminating EC2 instances or deleting EBS volumes. Without this option, you will be asked to confirm each dangerous action interactively.
Turn on debugging output. In particular, this causes Charon to print a Python stack trace if an unhandled exception occurs.
Print a brief summary of Charon’s command line syntax.
Print Charon’s version number.
The location of the state file if --state is not used. It defaults to ./network.charon.
UUID or symbolic name of the deployment on which to operate. Can be overriden using the -d option.
AWS Access Key ID used to communicate with the Amazon EC2 cloud. Used if deployment.ec2.accessKeyId is not set in an EC2 machine’s configuration.
AWS Secret Access Key used to communicate with the Amazon EC2 cloud. It is only used if no secret key corresponding to the AWS Access Key ID is defined in ~/.ec2-keys.

This file maps AWS Access Key IDs to their corresponding Secret Access Keys. Each line must consist of an Access Key IDs, a Secret Access Keys and an optional symbolic identifier, separated by whitespace. Comments starting with # are stripped. An example:
AKIAIUTDLWJKSLSJDLDQ Grsjf37cDKKWndklek3jdxnSKE3fkskDLqdldDl/ dev # AWS development account AKIAEODJSLXMDLLJKDLW DLeodsk32kldlDLSKdflexfpgiklf130r4dl23qp prod # AWS production account
The identifier can be used instead of actual Access Key IDs in deployment.ec2.accessKeyId, e.g.
deployment.ec2.accessKeyId = "prod";
This is useful if you have an AWS account with multiple user accounts and you don’t want to hard-code an Access Key ID in a Charon specification.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This command creates a new deployment state record in Charon’s database. The paths of the Nix expressions that specify the desired deployment (nixexprs) are stored in the state file. The UUID of the new deployment is printed on standard output.

listitem.para: Add path to the Nix expression search path for all future evaluations of the deployment specification. Charon stores path in the state file. This option may be given multiple times. See the description of the -I option in nix-instantiate1 for details.

Set the symbolic name of the deployment to the given string. The name can be used to refer to the deployment by passing the option -d name or the environment variable CHARON_DEPLOYMENT=name to subsequent Charon invocations. This is typically more convenient than using the deployment’s UUID. However, names are not required to be unique; if you create multiple deployments with the same name, Charon will complain.

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.screen: $ charon create expr1.nix expr2.nix --name foo $ charon deploy -d foo

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This command modifies an existing deployment. The options are the same as for charon create.

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.para:
To change the Nix expressions specifying the deployment, and rename it from foo to bar:
$ charon rename -d foo -n bar expr3.nix expr4.nix
Note that -d identifies the existing deployment, while -n specifies its new name.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This command clones an existing deployment; that is, it create a new deployment that has the same deployment specification and parameters, but a different UUID and (optionally) name. Note that charon clone does not currently clone the state of the machines in the existing deployment. Thus, when you first run charon deploy on the cloned deployment, Charon will create new instances from scratch.

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.para:
To create a new deployment bar by cloning the deployment foo:
$ charon clone -d foo -n bar

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This command deletes a deployment from the state file. You must run charon destroy first to get rid of any previously instantiated machines in the deployment.

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.para:
To delete the deployment named foo:
$ charon delete -d foo

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This command deploys a set of machines on the basis of the specification described by the Nix expressions given in the preceding charon create call. It creates missing virtual machines, builds each machine configuration, copies the closure of each configuration to the corresponding machine, and activates them.

listitem.para: Destroy (terminate) virtual machines that were previously created as part of this deployment, but are obsolete because they are no longer mentioned in the deployment specification. This happens if you remove a machine from the specification after having run charon deploy to create it. Without this flag, such obsolete machines are left untouched.
Dry run; show what would be done by this command without actually doing it.
Exit after creating any missing machines. Nothing is built and no existing machines are touched.

Just build the configuration locally; don’t create or deploy any machines. Note that this may fail if the configuration refers to information only known after machines have been created (such as IP addresses).
Exit after creating missing machines, building the configuration and copying closures to the target machines; i.e., do everything except activate the new configuration.

Normally, Charon assumes that the deployment state of machines doesn’t change behind its back. For instance, it assumes that a VirtualBox VM, once started, will continue to run unless you run charon destroy to terminate it. If this is not the case, e.g., because you shut down or destroyed a machine through other means, you should pass the --check option to tell Charon to verify its current knowledge.
Allow Charon to reboot the instance if necessary. For instance, if you change the type of an EC2 instance, Charon must stop, modify and restart the instance to effectuate this change.
Only operate on the machines explicitly mentioned here, excluding other machines.
Only operate on the machines that are not mentioned here.

Add path to the Nix expression search path. This option may be given multiple times and takes precedence over the -I flags used in the preceding charon create invocation. See the description of the -I option in nix-instantiate1 for details.
Use at most N concurrent nix-copy-closure processes to deploy closures to the target machines. N defaults to 5.

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.para:
To deploy all machines:
$ charon deploy

To deploy only the logical machines foo and bar, checking whether their recorded deployment state is correct:
$ charon deploy --check --include foo bar

To create any missing machines (except foo) without doing anything else:
$ charon deploy --create-only --exclude foo

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This command destroys (terminates) all virtual machines previously created as part of this deployment, and similarly deletes all disk volumes if they’re marked as “delete on termination”. Unless you pass the --confirm option, you will be asked to approve every machine destruction.

This command has no effect on machines that cannot be destroyed automatically; for instance, machines in the none target environment (such as physical machines, or virtual machines not created by Charon).

listitem.para: Only destroy the machines listed here.
Destroy all machines except the ones listed here.

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.para:
To destroy all machines:
$ charon destroy

To destroy the machine named foo:
$ charon destroy foo

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This command stops (shuts down) all non-obsolete machines that can be automatically started. This includes EC2 and VirtualBox machines, but not machines using the none backend (because Charon doesn’t know how to start them automatically).

listitem.para: Only stop the machines listed here.
Stop all machines except the ones listed here.

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.para:
To stop all machines that support being stopped:
$ charon stop

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This command starts all non-obsolete machines previously stopped using charon stop.

listitem.para: Only start the machines listed here.
Start all machines except the ones listed here.

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.para:
To start all machines that were previously stopped:
$ charon start

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This command prints information about all deployments in the database: the UUID, the name, the description, the number of running or stopped machines, and the types of those machines.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para:
This command prints some information about the current state of the deployment. For each machine, it prints:
The logical name of the machine.
Its state, which is one of New (not deployed yet), Up (created and up to date), Outdated (created but not up to date with the current configuration, e.g. due to use of the --exclude option to charon deploy) and Obsolete (created but no longer present in the configuration).
The type of the machine (i.e. the value of deployment.targetEnv, such as ec2). For EC2 machines, it also shows the machine’s region or availability zone.
The virtual machine identifier, if applicable. For EC2 machines, this is the instance ID. For VirtualBox VMs, it’s the virtual machine name.
The IP address of the machine. This is its public IP address, if it has one, or its private IP address otherwise. (For instance, VirtualBox machines only have a private IP address.)

listitem.para: Print information about all resources in all known deployments, rather than in a specific deployment.
Print the information in a more easily parsed format where columns are separated by tab characters and there are no column headers.
Do not evaluate the deployment specification. Note that as a consequence the “Status” field in the output will show all machines as “Obsolete” (since the effective deployment specification is empty).

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This command checks and prints the status of each machine in the deployment. For instance, for an EC2 machine, it will ask EC2 whether the machine is running or stopped. If a machine is supposed to be up, Charon will try to connect to the machine via SSH and get the current load average statistics.

listitem.para: Check all machines in all known deployments, rather than in a specific deployment.

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.para:
For a running VirtualBox instance, Charon will print something like:
$ charon status machine> VM state is ‘running’ machine> pinging SSH... up [1.03 0.34 0.12]

For a stopped EC2 instance, Charon might show:
machine> instance state is ‘stopped’

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This command opens an SSH connection to the specified machine and executes the specified command. If no command if specified, an interactive shell is started.

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.para:
To start a shell on machine foo:
$ charon ssh foo

To run Emacs on machine bar:
$ charon ssh bar -- -X emacs
Note the use of -- to force the flag -X (“enable X11 forwarding”) to be passed to SSH.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This operation executes the specified shell command on all non-obsolete machines.

listitem.para: Execute the command on each machine in parallel. The default is to do each machine sequentially.
Execute the command only on the machines listed here.
Execute the command on all machines except the ones listed here.

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.para:
To reboot all machines in parallel:
$ charon ssh-for-each -p reboot

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This command reboots all non-obsolete machines. If the option --parallel is given, the command is executed on all machines in parallel; otherwise, it’s executed sequentially.

listitem.para: Only reboot the machines listed here.
Reboot all machines except the ones listed here.
Do not wait until the machines have finished rebooting.

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.para:
To reboot all machines except foo and wait until they’re up again, that is, are reachable via SSH again:
$ charon reboot --exclude foo

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This command makes a backup of all persistent disks of all machines. Currently this is only implemented for EC2 EBS instances/volumes.

listitem.para: Only backup the persistent disks of the machines listed here.
Backup the persistent disks of all machines except the ones listed here.

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.para:
To backup the persistent disks of all machines:
$ charon backup

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This command restores a machine to a backup.

listitem.para: Only backup the persistent disks of the machines listed here.
Restore the persistent disks of all machines to a given backup except the ones listed here.
Restore the persistent disks of all machines to a given backup except the ones listed here.

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.para:
To list the available backups and restore the persistent disks of all machines to a given backup:
$ charon backup-status $ charon restore 20120803151302

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This command prints the value of the specified NixOS configuration option for the specified machine.

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.screen:
$ charon show-option machine services.xserver.enable false
$ charon show-option --xml machine boot.initrd.availableKernelModules <?xml version='1.0' encoding='utf-8'?> <expr> <list> <string value="md_mod" /> <string value="raid0" /> … </list> </expr>

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This command persistently sets arguments to be passed to the deployment specification.

listitem.para: Set the function argument name to value, where the latter is an arbitrary Nix expression.
Like --arg, but the value is a literal string rather than a Nix expression. Thus, --argstr name value is equivalent to --arg name \"value\".
Remove a previously set function argument.

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.para:
Consider the following deployment specification (servers.nix):
{ nrMachines, active }:
with import <nixpkgs/pkgs/lib>;
let
makeMachine = n: nameValuePair "webserver-${toString n}" ({ config, pkgs, ... }: { deployment.targetEnv = "virtualbox"; services.httpd.enable = active; services.httpd.adminAddr = "foo@example.org"; });
in listToAttrs (map makeMachine (range 1 nrMachines))
This specifies a network of nrMachines identical VirtualBox VMs that run the Apache web server if active is set. To create 10 machines without Apache:
$ charon create servers.nix $ charon set-args --arg nrMachines 10 --arg active false $ charon deploy
Next we can enable Apache on the existing machines:
$ charon set-args --arg active true $ charon deploy
or provision additional machines:
$ charon set-args --arg nrMachines 20 $ charon deploy

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This command prints the console output of the specified machine, if available. Currently this is only supported for the EC2 backend.

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.screen: $ charon show-console-output machine Xen Minimal OS! [ 0.000000] Initializing cgroup subsys cpuset [ 0.000000] Initializing cgroup subsys cpu [ 0.000000] Linux version 3.2.36 (nixbld@) (gcc version 4.6.3 (GCC) ) #1 SMP Fri Jan 4 16:07:14 UTC 2013 …
